awd_titl_txt: CoPe EAGER: Establishing Interface Standards for Physical Exposure and Human Impacts Data Collection and Publication in Rapid Response to Coastal Hazards
awd_abstract_narration:
Rapid response research is critical to understanding community resilience in the face of coastal hazards, such as tropical storms and flooding events. Yet, on-the-ground data collection efforts following these events are often uncoordinated and occur in different locations with different data collection approaches. The proposed work will establish standards to help coordinate rapid response data collection following major disasters.  A coordinated approach to these efforts will improve the research community's ability to analyze and understand the impacts that disasters have on human livelihoods and the policy responses that are likely to protect at-risk communities from disaster exposures and improve recoveries in disaster-stricken communities.  This research will democratize large data sets, enabling PIs with reduced research capacity to utilize multiple data sources, in order to test hypotheses related to coastlines and people. Further, this project will train one graduate student as well as a recently graduated undergraduate student through the NCAR SOARS program, which helps to broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in the sciences.
The multidisciplinary project (atmospheric science, economics, engineering, and epidemiology) aims to define and document several standardized data formats that could be useful for integrated hazard exposure and human impact research, as well as provide software tools and a case study of the use of these standardized data formats, aiming to increase the value of open access data repositories. The multidisciplinary team will develop and apply interface standards for coastal hazard exposure data that enable use with human impacts analysis. The project will identify common levels of temporal and spatial aggregation that are used for researching human impacts of coastal hazard exposures, which will improve the reproducibility of research in the context of coastlines and people. Open-source software tools that reformat and enable visualization, exploration, and modeling of data by the broader research community will then be developed and published, removing barriers that are created by incompatibilities in data structure and format across related projects. A case study analysis will combine novel birth outcomes and groundwater pollution datasets from Hurricanes Matthew, Michael and Florence.  This exercise will display the value of analyzing rapid response data in its native form while highlighting the broader intellectual benefits from reformatting and releasing data to the scientific community for re-analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

por.por_cntn:
Overview
The project aimed to establish standardized data formats and develop open-source software tools to enhance the integration and usability of hazard exposure data and human impact research in the context of coastal hazards. By creating these standards and tools, the project sought to improve the reproducibility and comparability of research across multiple disciplines, ultimately aiding in disaster preparedness and public health interventions.

Intellectual Merit
The primary intellectual contributions of the project include the development of standardized data formats for coastal hazard exposure data and the creation of open-source software tools to facilitate data integration and analysis. The project identified common units of spatial and temporal aggregation used in environmental epidemiology, economics, and engineering, which are essential for consistent and precise data analysis.

Key outcomes include the creation of the hurricaneexposuredata and hurricanezip R packages, which provide county-level and ZIP code-level hurricane exposure data, respectively. These tools enable researchers to access standardized data for their analyses, improving the accuracy and relevance of exposure assessments in epidemiological studies.

The project also updated the stormwindmodel package to model tropical cyclone wind speeds more efficiently, incorporating C++ to enhance performance. This improvement allows for more accurate historical exposure assessments at finer spatial scales, advancing the methodological approaches used in environmental health research.

Broader Impacts
The broader impacts of the project extend beyond academia to public health and policy. By providing standardized data formats and open-source tools, the project has set a benchmark for future research in hazard exposure and human impacts. These tools support interdisciplinary studies on disaster impacts, resource management, and community resilience, promoting collaborative efforts to address complex environmental challenges.

The project's case study in North Carolina demonstrated the practical application of standardized data formats by linking hurricane exposure data to waterborne contamination and adverse birth outcomes. This application highlighted the importance of high-resolution, standardized data in understanding and mitigating the human impacts of coastal hazards.

Additionally, the project's findings have significant societal impacts. Accurate data on hurricane exposure can inform evacuation plans and resource allocation during natural disasters, improving community resilience and public safety. The project's insights into the health impacts of hurricanes can guide public health interventions, ultimately benefiting vulnerable populations.

Summary of Outcomes
Standardized Data Formats: Established common units of spatial and temporal aggregation for hazard exposure data, improving the reproducibility and comparability of research.

Open-Source Software Tools: Developed the hurricaneexposuredata and hurricanezip R packages for standardized hurricane exposure data at county and ZIP code levels. Updated the stormwindmodel package for efficient modeling of tropical cyclone wind speeds.

Empirical Findings: Demonstrated the link between hurricane exposure and adverse birth outcomes, and the connection between flooding events and microbial contamination in private wells.

Professional Development: Supported the training and career growth of graduate and post-doctoral researchers, enhancing their expertise in environmental health and hazard exposure research.

Public Health and Policy Impact: Provided valuable resources for public health officials and policymakers, aiding in disaster preparedness and response, and informing public health interventions.

The project has made substantial contributions to the field of coastal hazard research, providing essential tools, methodologies, and empirical evidence that will support future studies and inform public health and policy decisions.


Last Modified: 07/02/2024
Modified by: Jacob Hochard
